path_1.title: The Prison (2017)
path_1.feeling: Gritty prison power-play scratched my itch for twisty Korean crime.

path_1.title: The Adam Project (2022)
path_1.feeling: Light, quippy time-travel fun but too safe and sentimental for me.

path_1.title: Himizu (2011)
path_1.feeling: Bleak, raw spiral into despair that resonates with my taste for dark character studies.

path_1.title: Honest Candidate (2020)
path_1.feeling: The conceit is cute, but the broad comedy left me lukewarm.

path_1.title: Tazza: The Hidden Card (2014)
path_1.feeling: Colorful gambling caper with energy, though it overindulges.

path_1.title: Jodorowsky's Dune (2013)
path_1.feeling: Even with the subject I like, a documentary format just turns me off.

path_1.title: Holy Mountain, The (Montaña sagrada, La) (1973)
path_1.feeling: Audacious, hypnotic surrealism that I admire more than I connect with.

path_1.title: The Piper (2015)
path_1.feeling: Folk horror mood worked, even if the payoff isn’t transcendent.

path_1.title: Notorious (1946)
path_1.feeling: Elegant suspense and fraught romance—classic Hitchcock that still sings.

path_1.title: Beasts Clawing at Straws (2020)
path_1.feeling: Knotted, brutal and witty—my favorite flavor of Korean noir.

path_1.title: On Your Wedding Day (2018)
path_1.feeling: Bittersweet beats land, though it stretches its nostalgia.

path_1.title: Timecrimes (Cronocrímenes, Los) (2007)
path_1.feeling: Lean, clever loop thriller that plays fair and stays tense.

path_1.title: De Premier (2016)
path_1.feeling: High-concept hostage stakes delivered brisk, satisfying thrills.

path_1.title: The Eight Hundred (2020)
path_1.feeling: Spectacle impresses more than the character work.

path_1.title: True Grit (2010)
path_1.feeling: Straight-shooting western craft with bite and heart.

path_1.title: Joint Security Area (Gongdong gyeongbi guyeok JSA) (2000)
path_1.feeling: Human, tense, and quietly devastating—right in my wheelhouse.

path_1.title: Midsommar (2019)
path_1.feeling: Gorgeous dread, a touch indulgent, but I enjoyed the slow-burn spiral.

path_1.title: Jojo Rabbit (2019)
path_1.feeling: Charming and pointed, though its tonal tightrope wobbles for me.

path_1.title: The Outfit (2022)
path_1.feeling: Talky, tight crime chamber piece that kept me grinning.

path_1.title: Good Will Hunting (1997)
path_1.feeling: Earnest, well-acted drama that hits familiar notes effectively.

path_1.title: Take Shelter (2011)
path_1.feeling: Paranoia and domestic dread handled with haunting precision.

path_1.title: Z (1969)
path_1.feeling: Righteously furious political thriller that still crackles.

path_1.title: Encanto (2021)
path_1.feeling: Vibrant and heartfelt, but the family musical vibe isn’t my thing.

path_1.title: 5 Centimeters per Second (Byôsoku 5 senchimêtoru) (2007)
path_1.feeling: Quiet heartbreak and distance that lingered with me.

path_1.title: The Berlin File (2013)
path_1.feeling: Bruising spy action with just enough intrigue to hook me.

path_1.title: Labyrinth (1986)
path_1.feeling: Whimsical oddity I appreciate more for its imagination than its story.

path_1.title: Abyss, The (1989)
path_1.feeling: Undersea sci-fi adventure with awe and tension in balance.

path_5.title: Encanto (2021)
path_5.feeling: Colorful and heartfelt, but the family musical mode leaves me mostly unmoved.

path_5.title: 5 Centimeters per Second (Byôsoku 5 senchimêtoru) (2007)
path_5.feeling: Lush, wistful drift of distance and time resonates, if a bit air-light for me.

path_5.title: The Berlin File (2013)
path_5.feeling: Sleek spy crossfire and divided loyalties satisfy even when it’s formulaic.

path_5.title: Labyrinth (1986)
path_5.feeling: Inventive whimsy charms in spots, but the fantasy froth isn’t my lane.

path_5.title: Abyss, The (1989)
path_5.feeling: Deep-sea awe and peril engage, even as the sentiment runs a little thick.

path_5.title: The Prison (2017)
path_5.feeling: Brutal, inside-the-walls crime machine hits my pulpy, noir-scheme itch.

path_5.title: The Adam Project (2022)
path_5.feeling: Quippy time-travel comfort food—easy to watch, light to the touch.

path_5.title: Himizu (2011)
path_5.feeling: Bleak teen spiral and moral ruin that I sink into.

path_5.title: Honest Candidate (2020)
path_5.feeling: High-concept honesty gags amuse but stay broad for me.

path_5.title: Tazza: The Hidden Card (2014)
path_5.feeling: Flashy gambling cons and rivalries entertain without cutting deep.

path_5.title: Jodorowsky's Dune (2013)
path_5.feeling: Film-dream lore fascinates, though the doc mode keeps me a bit distant.

path_5.title: Holy Mountain, The (Montaña sagrada, La) (1973)
path_5.feeling: Alchemical spectacle I admire more than I fully love.

path_5.title: The Piper (2015)
path_5.feeling: Folk-horror fable with postwar dread—moody and satisfying.

path_5.title: Notorious (1946)
path_5.feeling: Silken espionage and romantic peril—classic suspense that still works.

path_5.title: Beasts Clawing at Straws (2020)
path_5.feeling: Twisty, pitiless crime mosaic that thrills me.

path_5.title: On Your Wedding Day (2018)
path_5.feeling: Bittersweet near-misses land gently, if not profoundly.

path_5.title: Timecrimes (Cronocrímenes, Los) (2007)
path_5.feeling: Tight, nasty time-loop complications scratch my paranoia itch.

path_5.title: De Premier (2016)
path_5.feeling: High-stakes premise hooks me even as plausibility wobbles.

path_5.title: The Eight Hundred (2020)
path_5.feeling: Siege-pageantry impresses while emotional bite stays moderate for me.

path_5.title: True Grit (2010)
path_5.feeling: Flinty pursuit and dry humor—solid, satisfying western heft.

path_5.title: Joint Security Area (Gongdong gyeongbi guyeok JSA) (2000)
path_5.feeling: Border tragedy and shifting truths—exactly my kind of tense human puzzle.

path_5.title: Midsommar (2019)
path_5.feeling: Sunlit ritual dread I respect more than I love.

path_5.title: Jojo Rabbit (2019)
path_5.feeling: Twee-provocative mix lands as warm but a bit too cutesy for me.

path_5.title: The Outfit (2022)
path_5.feeling: One-room crime chess game with elegant tension—right up my alley.

path_5.title: Good Will Hunting (1997)
path_5.feeling: Earnest breakthrough drama that moves me if a touch tidy.

path_5.title: Take Shelter (2011)
path_5.feeling: Apocalypse paranoia and domestic dread—grips me hard.

path_5.title: Z (1969)
path_5.feeling: Righteous, propulsive political outrage that hits my sweet spot.

path_5.title: Encanto (2021)
path_5.feeling: Colorful, heartfelt family magic that charms more than it captivates me.

path_5.title: 5 Centimeters per Second (Byôsoku 5 senchimêtoru) (2007)
path_5.feeling: Lyrical distance and longing that I appreciate at arm’s length.

path_5.title: The Berlin File (2013)
path_5.feeling: Cold-war style spy churn with sharp momentum—very much my thing.

path_5.title: Labyrinth (1986)
path_5.feeling: Imaginative, offbeat quest whose charm outweighs its fluff for me.

path_5.title: Abyss, The (1989)
path_5.feeling: Deep-sea awe and tension deliver sturdy, high-concept thrills.

path_5.title: The Prison (2017)
path_5.feeling: Corrupt-prison power plays and infiltration scratch my Korean crime itch.

path_5.title: The Adam Project (2022)
path_5.feeling: Quippy time-hop adventure entertains but stays too slick and sentimental for my taste.

path_5.title: Himizu (2011)
path_5.feeling: Bleak teen spiral into violence and despair hits my dark, bruising lane.

path_5.title: Honest Candidate (2020)
path_5.feeling: High-concept truth-telling gag is amiable but too broad to really grab me.

path_5.title: Tazza: The Hidden Card (2014)
path_5.feeling: Flashy gambling underworld and fatal hustles satisfy even if it runs familiar.

path_5.title: Jodorowsky's Dune (2013)
path_5.feeling: Visionary-scheme autopsy and mad ambition intrigue me enough despite my doc fatigue.

path_5.title: Holy Mountain, The (Montaña sagrada, La) (1973)
path_5.feeling: Alchemical, blasphemous pageant of symbols and cruelty taps my surreal, transgressive sweet spot.

path_5.title: The Piper (2015)
path_5.feeling: Folk-horror paranoia and postwar rot build a moody, satisfying chill.

path_5.title: Notorious (1946)
path_5.feeling: Silky spy romance and moral compromise deliver the classic tension I savor.

path_5.title: Beasts Clawing at Straws (2020)
path_5.feeling: Cruel, crisscrossing fates and money-bag desperation are catnip to me.

path_5.title: On Your Wedding Day (2018)
path_5.feeling: Bittersweet near-misses and time’s drift land as sincere, low-key romance.

path_5.title: Timecrimes (Cronocrímenes, Los) (2007)
path_5.feeling: Tight, nasty time-loop spiral scratches my paranoid-thriller itch hard.

path_5.title: De Premier (2016)
path_5.feeling: High-concept political coercion grips even if it plays a bit pulpy.

path_5.title: The Eight Hundred (2020)
path_5.feeling: Siege heroics impress on scale and grit, though it keeps me half-removed.

path_5.title: True Grit (2010)
path_5.feeling: Flinty pursuit, moral reckonings, and dry humor hit a sturdy, satisfying groove.

path_5.title: Joint Security Area (Gongdong gyeongbi guyeok JSA) (2000)
path_5.feeling: Border-bred friendship and investigation unwind into the kind of moral ache I love.

path_5.title: Midsommar (2019)
path_5.feeling: Sun-drenched dread and cult rituals work on me even as the sprawl shows.

path_5.title: Jojo Rabbit (2019)
path_5.feeling: Satirical whimsy and wartime heart mostly land, if a shade tidy for me.

path_5.title: The Outfit (2022)
path_5.feeling: Contained crime chess match and precise character turns are right up my alley.

path_5.title: Good Will Hunting (1997)
path_5.feeling: Therapy, guilt, and potential play earnest and engaging, if a touch tidy.

path_5.title: Take Shelter (2011)
path_5.feeling: Apocalypse visions and domestic dread burrow under my skin in the best way.

path_5.title: Z (1969)
path_5.feeling: Righteous, propulsive political outrage and conspiracy gears hit my sweet spot.

path_5.title: Encanto (2021)
path_5.feeling: Colorful, heartfelt family magic charms even if it’s lighter than my lane.

path_5.title: 5 Centimeters per Second (Byôsoku 5 senchimêtoru) (2007)
path_5.feeling: Melancholy distance and quiet heartbreak resonate on craft and mood.

path_5.title: The Berlin File (2013)
path_5.feeling: Hard-edged spy maneuvers and divided-loyalty heat give me the thrills I want.

path_5.title: Labyrinth (1986)
path_5.feeling: Inventive puppet fantasy and coming-of-age quest charm, if lightly for me.

path_5.title: Abyss, The (1989)
path_5.feeling: Deep-sea peril and awe deliver sturdy, humanist sci-fi I can sink into.
